experience: You and Carl both know Sean Sheppard, Carl Ford, and 84 others
I made an OFFER to someone. I then get a call from his former boss, whom I knew from one of my previous jobs and was friendly with.
He says -  “Oleg, the guy you made the offer to is terrible, he screwed everything up here. I was going to fire him.”
I said “thank you” but not only I did not rescind the offer, my opinion of the candidate did not change.
Firstly, his prior track record was immaculate except for this alleged screw up.
Secondly, people are allowed mistakes, we are all human. It is what we learn from mistakes that matters.
Thirdly, I learned to trust my own instincts – this candidate was the real thing.
Needless to say, I was right.
The employee was stellar, and within a year I promoted him to a technical management position.
He is still there, years after I left – appreciated by every manager and colleague.
As for that screwing everything up, I learned later it was not his doing at all !
Here is another example, read this shocking pizza INTERVIEW post:
It's an recruiting industry term that all candidates should be familiar with.
A job order comes from a company that the recruiter or recruiting agency has partnered with and is for a specific position in a specific geography at a specific salary.

Sometimes companies release multiple job orders to the same firm and recruiter, sometimes they release the same job order to multiple agencies, and sometimes they release just one job order to one agency or one recruiter.

Once the agency has the job order in hand, they can go about recruiting for it (or looking through their candidate lists and finding old candidates who might be a good fit-- these might be candidates they talked to a week ago, they might be candidates they talked to 3 years ago.)
Whatever it takes, a recruiter tries to fill the job order as fast as possible to beat the other agencies or the other recruiters in their own firm.

Listen: this is YOUR life and YOUR career. It's perfectly OK to ask a recruiter if they are reaching out to you because of a specific job order or if they are just "pipelining" or "marketing resumes."
A young woman messaged me on LinkedIn.
She said, "I'm at a crossroads. I want to found a company, but I have an offer to work in real estate."
I replied, "What are the benefits of each?"
"People tell me I'd be great at real estate."
When I started writing, all my friends and family laughed for years.
I don't blame them. I was an awful writer.
Even when I published my first book, they didn't take me seriously.
It took five years, thousands of articles, and three books before I developed a loyal audience and earned their respect.
I wouldn't trade it for anything in the world.
I then said, "What you believe you can become is far different than what others believe. The best thing you can do is trust yourself first.
What does your gut say you want to do with your life?"
But we both knew the answer.
It's not my job to tell her what route to pick.
Nor is it the job of her family and friends.
She already knew the right decision.
I took a call with the founder of a marketing agency who wanted to partner with our venture capital firm. The founder wouldn't stop talking about the company's accomplishments.
"We've made our clients a lot of money. We work with the best startups."
He wasn't explaining how he could help us.
I was fishy about his approach, so I used my trick to identify liars.
"Tell me about a time when your client didn't get their desired result. A time when you failed."
I was looking to see if he would take responsibility for the failure. If he did, then I'd consider his proposal.
After each of his statements, here's what I thought:
He should've said, "We didn't vet the company."
He should've said, "We didn't set the right expectations."
"They didn't have enough leverage with their assets."
He should've said, "We didn't correctly assess the value of their assets."
Knowing how to deal with failure is a critical piece of success. If you blame others, then you won't improve.
It shows you have an ego and fail to take responsibility when things go south.
That's a sign you're a liar.
Lately, I have had some (237ish) requests from frustrated candidates about the “big picture” of recruiting:
We’re going to do an old fashioned #jonstewart as #glennbeck “follow the money.”
Not paying anything or getting anything: Candidate
You, the Candidate are NOT the Client.
Recruiting is a service like any other service. If recruiting was a haircut, the recruiter would be the hairdresser, the client would be the one getting the haircut and YOU, the candidate?
You? Well, you are the gosh darn scissors. A very, shiny, special, exotic kind of sciossors that the client can only dream about finding on their own.
You’re the tool/method from which the servicer (recruiter) delivers the service to the client (company hiring).
As a bonus to this you can be introduced to entire new careers and opportunities that you never knew existed or that you were qualified for.
That’s WAY better than being a pair of scissors.
And recruiters should treat you, your career and your next opportunity with the respect you deserve because you are not scissors. You are a person.
But in the end: FOLLOW the MONEY, Honey.

March 14, 2017, Carl reported directly to Debbi

Bottom-line, Debbi is the best leader I've had the privilege to work with, and for.  She empowers, listens, guides, and trusts.  She epitomizes the ideal personality and character of the HR professional.  She saw our organization through countless changes, and always remained a steady, calming leader in the organization.  Due to drastic change, Debbi's responsibilities were ever increasing, but she somehow made it seem effortless.  Her commitment to the company and the role are commendable, and she did not take the responsibility lightly, and she juggled a great deal, in HR and otherwise.  She is an expert in most things HR and I learned a great deal from her that will help me in the future.  Finally, Debbi is just a great person.  You'd be tough pressed to find people that have worked with Debbi that don't consider her a friend.  She is worthy of my highest recommendation.
